Classic Pecan Pie

Jump to Recipe

Welcome to the world of delightful desserts where we explore the timeless classic: Pecan Pie. This indulgent treat, characterized by its rich, gooey filling and crunchy pecan topping, is a must-have during the fall and holiday seasons. Whether you're hosting a Thanksgiving feast or simply craving a slice of something sweet, this Pecan Pie recipe brings together simple ingredients to create a mouthwatering experience that will leave everyone asking for seconds. Packed with the nutty flavor of pecans and the sweetness of brown sugar and corn syrup, every bite of this pie is a celebration of comfort food at its finest. Join me as we dive into this easy-to-follow recipe that promises to elevate your dessert game and impress your guests!

Ingredients

pecan halves

Use fresh pecan halves for the best flavor and crunch. If you need a substitute, walnuts can work, but they will change the flavor profile significantly. Toasting the pecans lightly before adding them to the filling can enhance their nuttiness.

corn syrup

Light corn syrup is traditional for pecan pie, but you can substitute with maple syrup or honey for a different flavor. If using maple syrup, consider reducing the sugar slightly as it is sweeter than corn syrup.

brown sugar

Use light brown sugar for a milder molasses flavor or dark brown sugar for a richer taste. If you don't have brown sugar, you can substitute with granulated sugar mixed with a tablespoon of molasses.

eggs

Eggs help to bind the filling together, so it's important to use fresh eggs. If you need a substitute for dietary reasons, you can use 1/4 cup of unsweetened applesauce or a flax egg (1 tablespoon ground flaxseed mixed with 2.5 tablespoons water) for each egg.

vanilla extract

Pure vanilla extract is always preferred for the best flavor. If you don’t have any, you can use vanilla bean paste or even a drop of almond extract for a different yet pleasant flavor twist.

salt

Salt enhances the sweetness of the pie, so don't skip it. If you're looking for a substitute, you can use sea salt or kosher salt, but remember that the texture and flavor can vary slightly.

pie crust

A homemade pie crust will give your pecan pie a fresh taste, but store-bought is a convenient option. If you're looking for a gluten-free option, there are pre-made gluten-free pie crusts available, or you can make a crust with ground nuts and butter.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Preheat the Oven

    Set your oven to 350°F (175°C). This is a crucial step as it ensures even baking of your pecan pie.

  • Step 2: Mix the Filling

    In a large mixing bowl, whisk together 1 cup of corn syrup, 1 cup of brown sugar, 3 eggs, 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract, and 1/4 teaspoon of salt until the mixture is smooth and fully combined. Make sure to incorporate the sugar well to avoid any graininess in the filling.

  • Step 3: Add the Pecans

    Gently stir in 1 cup of pecan halves into the mixture. Ensure all the pecans are evenly coated with the filling. This step is important as it distributes the pecans throughout the pie.

  • Step 4: Prepare the Pie Crust

    Take your 9-inch pie crust and place it on a baking sheet to catch any drips during baking. If using a store-bought crust, follow the package instructions for pre-baking if necessary.

  • Step 5: Fill the Pie Crust

    Pour the pecan filling into the prepared pie crust, spreading the pecans evenly to ensure a nice presentation. Be careful not to overfill the crust.

  • Step 6: Bake the Pie

    Place the pie in the preheated oven and bake for 60 minutes or until the filling is set and slightly puffed. Check the pie halfway through baking and rotate it for even cooking.

  • Step 7: Cool the Pie

    Remove the pie from the oven and let it cool for at least 2 hours before slicing. This cooling time allows the filling to firm up, making it easier to slice.

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I prepare pecan halves for pie?

Pecan halves don't require much preparation! You can use them straight from the package. If you want to enhance their flavor, consider toasting them in a dry skillet over medium heat for 5-7 minutes until fragrant.

What is the best way to measure corn syrup?

Corn syrup is sticky, so to make measuring easier, lightly spray the measuring cup with cooking spray before pouring in the syrup. This will help it slide out smoothly!

How do I know when the pie is done baking?

The pie is done when the filling is set and slightly puffed. It should jiggle slightly in the center but not be liquid. You can also use a toothpick; if it comes out clean from the filling, the pie is ready.

What should I do if my pie crust is too soft?

If your pie crust is too soft and difficult to work with, chill it in the refrigerator for about 30 minutes. This will help it firm up and be easier to handle.

How long should I let the pecan pie cool?

Let the pie cool for at least 2 hours before slicing. This cooling time allows the filling to firm up, making it easier to cut clean slices.

Is it safe to eat undercooked eggs in the pie?

To ensure food safety, it's best to use pasteurized eggs in recipes that are not fully cooked. If you're concerned, look for pasteurized eggs at your grocery store.

Can I make pecan pie ahead of time?

Yes! Pecan pie can be made a day ahead of serving. Just cover it with plastic wrap after it cools completely and store it in the refrigerator.

What if I don't have vanilla extract?

If you don't have vanilla extract, you can substitute it with an equal amount of almond extract for a different flavor profile, or simply omit it for a more straightforward pecan flavor.

How can I prevent my pie crust from burning?

To prevent the crust from burning, you can cover the edges of the crust with aluminum foil during the last 15-20 minutes of baking. This will protect the crust while allowing the filling to cook.

What can I do with leftover pecan pie?

Leftover pecan pie can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 4 days. Simply cover it tightly to maintain freshness. You can enjoy it cold or reheated in the microwave for a few seconds.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

This Classic Pecan Pie contains gluten and is not suitable for vegans due to the eggs and traditional pie crust. For gluten-free options, use a gluten-free pie crust. To make it vegan, substitute eggs with a flaxseed meal or chia seed mixture (1 tablespoon of seeds mixed with 2.5 tablespoons of water per egg) and use a vegan pie crust. Additionally, ensure that the corn syrup used is free of any animal products if catering to strict dietary preferences.

Pairings

For a delightful pairing with Classic Pecan Pie, consider serving it with a scoop of vanilla ice cream or a dollop of freshly whipped cream to complement the pie's rich sweetness. A glass of sweet dessert wine, such as a Sauternes or a late-harvest Riesling, enhances the nutty flavors. If you prefer a non-alcoholic option, a warm cup of spiced chai tea or apple cider can also be a great choice.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the Classic Pecan Pie at room temperature or slightly warmed. For an elegant presentation, slice the pie into wedges and serve on a decorative plate. Garnish each slice with a sprinkle of sea salt or a few extra pecan halves for a refined touch. Consider serving it with a side of caramel sauce or chocolate drizzle for added indulgence.

Classic Pecan Pie

75 min
$12
450 kcal
Difficulty: 20%
Servings: 8

Allergens:

NutsGlutenEggs

Dietary Tags:

Vegetarian

Cuisine:

AmericanSouthern

Course:

Dessert

Tags:

DessertPieAmerican

Description

A rich and sweet pie filled with pecans and a gooey, buttery filling, perfect for any occasion!

Ingredients

  • pecan halves: 1 cup
  • corn syrup: 1 cup
  • brown sugar: 1 cup
  • eggs: 3
  • vanilla extract: 1 teaspoon
  • salt: 1/4 teaspoon
  • pie crust: 1 (9-inch)

Date Created:

11/16/2024
